STW Relevant: The ACT Profile Reports have information about students' perspective major and post-secondary educational aspiriations (Voc-Tech, Associates), which relates to STW majors and levels of education.
Subject: Education
Purpose: The ACT Profile Reports contain information about students who took the ACT test.
Data Quality Assessments: https://www.fairtest.org/act-biased-inaccurate-and-misused
Data Format: PDFs on state level, Other Not specified.
Notes: Data can be requested from the form at the bottom of the page: https://www.act.org/content/act/en/research/services-and-resources/data-and-visualization.html

STW Relevant: The National Guide provides a list of accreditation recommendations for various courses and trainings provided by businesses, educational institutions, and other organizations. This connects to STW, as many of these educational opportunities are in the skilled-technical domain. For example, JetBlue offers classes towards a college degree, including "Introduction to Electromagnetism" which is related to skilled-technical education.
Dataset Name: ACE National Guide to College Credit
Subject: Education, Licenses/Certification
Purpose: "The ACE National Guide to College Credit for Workforce Training contains ACE credit recommendations for formal courses or examinations offered by various organizations, from businesses and unions to the government and military."
Audience: Businesses, organizations, and postsecondary institutions looking to have educational and training programs accredited; students looking for educational and training opportunities.
Population Coverage: The population is educational programs who requested the review of ACE and received accreditation.
Data Quality Assessments: NA

STW Relevant: The database lists accrediting organization, link to general education page, link to distance learning page, and keywords. This is relevant to STW, because many of the accrediting organization are in STW industries and offer STW-related credentials.
Subject: Education Licenses/Certifications
Purpose: A one-stop resource for online education and distance-learning resources provided by ANSI-accredited standards developers, ANSI members and other academic institutions.
Population Coverage: The population is online education/distance-learning opportunities from ANSI-accredited standards developers, members,and institutions.
Data Quality Assessments: A bias of the data is that it only includes ANSI-accredited opportunities.

STW Relevant: Provides job gain and loss trends by state and broad occupation categories that may provide insight STW program development.
Subject: Employment
Purpose: "Business Employment Dynamics data are quarterly series of gross job gains and gross job losses statistics for the entire economy. These data track changes in employment at the establishment level, and thus provide a picture of the dynamics underlying aggregate net employment growth statistics."
Population Coverage: Workers covered by unemployment insurance (UI) and Unemployment Compensation for Federal Employees (UCFE)
Data Quality Assessments: See FAQ:   https://www.bls.gov/bdm/bdmfaq.htm
Notes: BLS Information Guide: https://www.bls.gov/bls/bureau-of-labor-statistics-information-guide.pdf

STW Relevant: Provides projections on growing occupations, occupations adding the most jobs, and the fastest growing industries that can be used in STW program development. See the Occupation Outlook Handbook https://www.bls.gov/ooh/.
Subject: Employment
Purpose: "The Employment Projections (EP) program develops information about the labor market for the Nation as a whole for 10 years in the future."
Audience: Researchers, Policy-makers, Business Community, and General Public
Data Quality Assessments: For a historical assessment of the quality of the projections see: https://www.bls.gov/opub/mlr/1999/05/art3full.pdf.
Notes: BLS Information Guide: https://www.bls.gov/bls/bureau-of-labor-statistics-information-guide.pdf

Subject: Unemployment, Employment
Purpose: "The LAUS program is a hierarchy of non-survey methodologies for producing monthly estimates of civilian labor force, employment, unemployment, and the unemployment rate for approximately 7,000 subnational areas."
Population Coverage: Civilian noninstitutional population ages 16 and older classified as either employed or unemployed
Geographic Unit: Census regions & divisions, States, MSA, Metropolitan NECTAS, Metropolitan Dvisions & NECTA Divisions, Combined MSA & Combined NECTAs, Small Labor Market Areas, Counties & county equivalents, Cities of 25,000 populations or more, Cities & towns in New England with populations of at least 1,000
Time Coverage: The LAUS monthly series start in January 1976 for census regions and divisions, all states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Los Angeles-Long Beach-Glendale Metropolitan Division, and New York city. Series for most substate areas begin in January 1990.
Data Quality Assessments: See Methodology Report Link
Notes: BLS Information Guide: https://www.bls.gov/bls/bureau-of-labor-statistics-information-guide.pdf

STW Relevant: Provides projections on growing occupations, occupations adding the most jobs, and the fastest growing industries that can be used in STW program development. See the Occupation Outlook Handbook https://www.bls.gov/ooh/.
Subject: Employment
Purpose: "Projections of occupational employment, occupation within industry employment, occupational separations, and information on education by occupation."
Audience: Researchers, Policy-makers, Business Community, and General Public
Data Quality Assessments: For a historical assessment of the quality of the projections see: https://www.bls.gov/opub/mlr/1999/05/art3full.pdf.
Notes: BLS Information Guide: https://www.bls.gov/bls/bureau-of-labor-statistics-information-guide.pdf

STW Relevant: Provides information on average wages as well as employment changes in specific positions over time.
Subject: Employment, Pay
Purpose: National industry-specific occupational employment and wage estimates are calculated with data collected from employers of all sizes, in metropolitan and nonmetropolitan areas in every state and the District of Columbia
Data Quality Assessments: The employment data are benchmarked to an average of the May and November employment levels.
Notes: BLS Information Guide: https://www.bls.gov/bls/bureau-of-labor-statistics-information-guide.pdf

STW Relevant: This data could be useful in determining STW/non-STW workers in an industry.
Subject: Jobs/Employment Industry
Purpose: Looks at percentage of workers in given industry who are STEM/non-STEM. Considers mostly STW jobs and also gives income averages.
When does the data become available?: The data usually becomes available on March of the following year
Methodology Report Link: This is the methodology for May 2018: https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes_tec.htm
Data Dictionary Link: Ther is no data dictionary, but there is a field description tab in the Excel download.
Data Quality Assessments: The employment data are benchmarked to an average of the May and November employment levels.
Notes: BLS Information Guide: https://www.bls.gov/bls/bureau-of-labor-statistics-information-guide.pdf

STW Relevant: Gives information on what percentage of workers by field and level of education.
Dataset Name: Occupational Employment Statistics, Typical Entry-Level Educational Requirement Datasets
Subject: Education Jobs/Employment Industry
Purpose: Looks at educational attainment by industry.
When does the data become available?: The data usually becomes available on March of the following year
Methodology Report Link: This is the methodology for May 2018: https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes_tec.htm
Data Dictionary Link: Ther is no data dictionary, but there is a field description tab in the Excel download.
Data Quality Assessments: The employment data are benchmarked to an average of the May and November employment levels.
Notes: BLS Information Guide: https://www.bls.gov/bls/bureau-of-labor-statistics-information-guide.pdf

STW Relevant: Quarterly employment and wage data collected by the state. De-identified and aggregated of state wage records. Data are agregated by NAIC code which can be identified as STW or non-STW.
Dataset Name: Quarterly Census of Employment and Wages  (QCEW)
Subject: Employment, Pay
Purpose: Data from the QCEW program serve as an important input to many BLS programs. The QCEW data are used as the benchmark source for employment by the?Current Employment Statistics?program and the?Occupational Employment Statistics?program. The UI administrative records collected under the QCEW program serve as a sampling frame for BLS establishment surveys.
Population Coverage: Employers with full- or part-time employees covered by state and federal unemployment insurance laws.
When does the data become available?: Five months after the end of each referenced quarter.
Data Quality Assessments: See Methodology Report Link
Notes: Data is not provided by occupation. We would need to understand the relationship between employment and job ads. (Establish relationship by comparing JOLTS to employment data).

STW Relevant: Can be integrated with the BGT resume data to provide information on the skills needed from employers for STW occupations that are not available in the current workforce. Provides data on the types of skills used in STW occupations that would require training beyond the high school but do not requires a bachelor's degree. Proivdes data on the non-degree credentials required by employers for STW occupations. Can provide data on how job seekers enter the STW - skills and post-secondary credentials that are needed.
Subject: Job-ads
Purpose: "Burning Glass Technologies is an analytics software company that has cracked the genetic code of an ever-changing labor market.  Powered by the world’s largest and most sophisticated database of labor market data and talent, we deliver real-time data and breakthrough planning tools that inform careers, define academic programs, and shape workforces."
Data Dictionary Link: No online data dictionary; data dictionary provided when you purchase the data.
Data Quality Assessments: See the UVA SDAD Burning Glass Technologies Job-ad Technology Report
Funding amount to support R&D: Funding amount not disclosed but conducts research with public and non-profit institutions: https://www.burning-glass.com/research/.

STW Relevant: Can be integrated with the BGT resume data to provide information on the skills needed from employers for STW occupations that are not available in the current workforce. Proivdes data on how job seekers advance and maintain relevence.
Subject: Resumes
Purpose: "Burning Glass Technologies is an analytics software company that has cracked the genetic code of an ever-changing labor market.  Powered by the world’s largest and most sophisticated database of labor market data and talent, we deliver real-time data and breakthrough planning tools that inform careers, define academic programs, and shape workforces."
Data Dictionary Link: No online data dictionary; data dictionary provided when you purchase the data.
Data Quality Assessments: See the UVA SDAD Burning Glass Technologies Job-ad Technology Report
Funding amount to support R&D: Funding amount not disclosed but conducts research with public and non-profits institution: https://www.burning-glass.com/research/.

STW Relevant: Skills in the STW-realm can be searched to find relevant information on compensation, supply/demand, top candidate titles, and top job titles.
Subject: Jobs/Employment, Industry, Employers
Purpose: "Talentstream Supply & Demand is a combination of CareerBuilder job seeker resumes, as well as workforce data from government sources and job postings from aggregators across the web."
Geographic Unit: Zip code, County, State, City, MSA
Data Quality Assessments: Since the exact sources of data used for Talent Stream is not listed on the website, the bias is unknown.
Funding amount to support R&D: Grants of up to $10,000 and data access through the Academic Research Collaboration program: https://hiring.careerbuilder.com/company/arc
Notes: Talent Stream claims to have demographic data, but is not clear about what their demographic data contains.

STW Relevant: Courses in STW related topics could be searched to see the availability of STW MOOC courses. The course descriptions and syllabi could also be searched for STW related skills. Class Central has a list of 148 credentials that can be received after completing a MOOC sequence and paying for the credential, many of which are relevant to the STW.
Subject: Education
Purpose: Class Central is a listing of massively open online courses (MOOC) that can be filtered by subject, university, or provider.
Data Dictionary Link: There is no data dictionary, but there is a taxonomy of online course subjects: https://github.com/classcentral/online-course-taxonomy
Data Quality Assessments: The Class Central data could be compared to other data from MOOC list and ranking websites, such as Coursera or edX.
Notes:
Class Central provides yearly "MOOC Roundup" publications, which looks at trends in MOOCs for that year. It is possible that they have further administrative data, so it may be useful to contact them. 
https://www.classcentral.com/report/tag/mooc-roundup-2018/

STW Relevant: The data will provide information including the educational program, education provider, attendance (in-person/online), part-time/full-time, location (city), type of credential (certificate, etc), average graduate salary, typical graduate job titles, tuition costs, and an example of a Climb loan. The educational program could be connected to STW skills, and provide information about educational pathways.
Subject: Education, Student Loans
Purpose: Climb Credit assesses alternative education and training programs with an ROI formula, which includes measures of tuition, graduation rate, job placement, borrowing costs, current income, and post-grad income. If a program passes their ROI calculations, they partner with those programs to provide student loans for training programs and assesses the programs it funds. The Compare Programs tool allows prospective students to view information about different programs verified by Climb Credit.
Audience: Potential alternative education program students who are looking for loans
Population Coverage: The population of the data is alternative education programs that pass Climb Credit's ROI assessment.
Data Quality Assessments: A bias of the data is that it only includes programs that pass Climb Credit's ROI measure.

STW Relevant: The College-Bound Seniors aggregated PDFs indicate that the College Board has STW-relevant information regarding SAT test-takes, specifically through their data on intended college majors and intended degree level. The College Board has a process for requesting this data on additional levels, including district and individual levels.
Dataset Name: SAT College-Bound Seniors/SAT Suite of Assessments
Subject: Education
Purpose: The SAT College-Bound Seniors data contains information for high school graduates who took the SAT by year.
Audience: Secondary Institutions, Postsecondary Institutions, Policymakers, Local/State Governments
Population Coverage: All seniors who took the SAT are counted. This is not representative of the total population of college-bound seniors, as some may take ACT, or not test at all.
Time Coverage: 1996-2016 (College-Bound Seniors - old SAT) 2017-2019 (SAT Suite of Assessments - new SAT)
Data Quality Assessments: The College Board completed a validity study published in 2019 which compares SAT scores with High School GPA (reported) and grades for first year students, to assess the SAT as an effective predicter of college performance.
Accessibility:
Webscraping (PDFS of aggregated data) 
Formal Request
Notes:
Release guidelines and forms:

https://research.collegeboard.org/pdf/rd-guide-release-data.pdf

https://research.collegeboard.org/about-us/request-data

STW Relevant: The Community for Accredited Online Schools provides information for vocational and trade schools. This information can be filtered by state, degree level (Associate's, career diploma), and subject. Many of the schools listed include links to the school's online program page. This data could be used to explore STW educational pathways.
Subject: Education, Licenses/Certification
Purpose: The Community for Accredited Online Schools aims to inform prospective students about accredited colleges.
Population Coverage: Accredited , not-for-profit United States trade and vocational schools with at least one online program.
Methodology Report Link:
There is a methodology pop-up on this page:
https://www.accreditedschoolsonline.org/vocational-trade-school/
Data Quality Assessments: The data only includes accredited and not-for-profit trade and vocational schools, so some trade and vocational schools are left out of the data.
Notes: Developed by ABUV a developer of content-rich websites. The company creates content-rich websites to help consumers make more informed decisions in areas such as education, career development and personal finance.

STW Relevant: The Community for Accredited Online Schools provides information for universities and colleges with online programs. This can be filtered to two-year universities, subject, and state. There is also descriptions of the institution, which provides links to online learning programs. The information could be used to explore STW educational pathways.
Subject: Education
Purpose: The Community for Accredited Online Schools aims to inform prospective students about accredited colleges.
Population Coverage: Accredited, not-for-profit United States colleges and universities with online programs.
Methodology Report Link:
There is a methodology pop-up on this page:
https://www.accreditedschoolsonline.org/online-colleges/
Data Quality Assessments: The data only includes accredited and not-for-profit institutions, so some institutions are left out of the data.
Notes: Developed by ABUV a developer of content-rich websites. The company creates content-rich websites to help consumers make more informed decisions in areas such as education, career development and personal finance.

Data Source Name: Coordinated by U.S. Census Bureau and developed under the Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD) program  https://lehd.ces.census.gov/
STW Relevant: Can determine earnings for community college graduates and certificate holders from specified institutions in different fields.
Subject: Employment
Purpose: Post-Secondary Employment Outcomes (PSEO) are experimental tabulations developed by the Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD) program in collaboration with post-secondary institutions and state agencies. PSEO data provide earnings and employment outcomes for college and university graduates by degree level, degree major, and post-secondary institution. The current PSEO is released as a research data product in "beta" form. The PSEO provide data on earnings and employment for recent graduates of partner colleges and universities. Graduate Earnings are available at the 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles, one, five, and 10 years after graduation, by institution, degree level, degree field, and graduation cohort. Employment Flows provide industry and location of employment for graduates.
Population Coverage: College and university graduates (in selected colleges in TX, WI, CO, and MI)
Data Quality Assessments: In Comparability to Other Data: "The College Scorecard is a data product released by the U.S. Department of Education beginning in 2013 and focuses on entering cohorts of students and their earnings ten years after initial enrollment, although they report longer-term outcomes as well. The Department of Education produces this product by matching federal financial aid data to IRS tax records. They report the 10th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 90th percentiles of earnings for students. However, the College Scorecard sample frame is only students who received federal financial aid, and these earnings may not reflect those of the entire population of students from that institution.
Notes: Only data from the University of Texas system, public institutions in Colorado, the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor, and the University of Wisconsin - Madison are available. Can filter for Community Colleges & Technical Colleges. These statistics are generated by matching university transcript data with a national database of jobs, using state-of-the-art confidentiality protection mechanisms to protect the underlying data- meaning could potentially request underlying data

Data Source Name: Coordinated by U.S. Census Bureau and developed under the Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD) program  https://lehd.ces.census.gov/
STW Relevant: This source provides information on employment, job creation, earnings, and other measures of employment flows that can be filtered by industries. This could provide information about the workforce in STW industries.
Subject: Employment
Purpose: The QWI are a set of 32 economic indicators including employment, job creation/destruction, wages, hires, and other measures of employment flows. The QWI are reported based on detailed firm characteristics (geography, industry, age, size) and worker demographics (sex, age, education, race, ethnicity) and are available tabulated to national*, state, metropolitan/micropolitan areas, county, and workforce investment areas (WIA). The QWI are unique in their ability to track both firm and worker characteristics over time – enabling analyses such as a longitudinal look at wages by worker sex and age across counties, ranking job creation rates of young firms across NAICS industry groups, and comparing hiring levels by worker race and education levels across a selection of metropolitan areas. LEHD data product.
Population Coverage: Workers covered by unemployment insurance (UI) and Unemployment Compensation for Federal Employees (UCFE)
Geographic Unit: U.S., State, Metropolitan/Micropolitan areas, County, and Workforce Investment Board (WIB) areas
When does the data become available?: The latest available data is three quarters behind the production quarter.
Notes:
This document is helpful: https://lehd.ces.census.gov/doc/QWI_101.pdf

Here is the application https://qwiexplorer.ces.census.gov/static/explore.html#x=0&g=0

Data Source Name: Council for the Adult & Experiential Learning
STW Relevant: CAEL has publications about competency-based education, which is a potential educational pathway for the STW. There are additional publications on adult learning and military-connected students and veterans, which could be useful for the project.
Subject: Education, Licenses/Certification
Purpose: "The leader in linking learning and work, the 501(c)(3) nonprofit Council for Adult and Experiential Learning (CAEL) pursues work at all levels within the public and private sectors to enhance learning opportunities for adults around the world."
Data Quality Assessments: NA
Notes: A majority of the fields for this source are left blank because there are no datasets on their website. However, they provide numerous publications on their website. There is a signup to access the publications. It may be worth reaching out to CAEL to see if they have any datasets they use in their publications that are relevant to this project.

Data Source Name: Council on Integrity in Results Reporting
STW Relevant: This data source provides information on select bootcamps, including campus location, course length, number of graduates, percent of students employed in-field, median salary of graduates, and most frequent job titles. The most frequent job titles can be connected to STW job titles, and provides information on the success of bootcamps for preparing the STW for jobs.
Subject: Education
Purpose:
"The Council on Integrity in Results Reporting (CIRR) is a non-profit organization whose members believe that prospective students should know a school's outcomes before deciding whether to enroll. The CIRR standards prevent deceptive graduation and job placement marketing practices and ensure a student can trust what a school advertises.

CIRR provides a standardized system for measuring and reporting student outcomes that all of its schools use. The measurement standards are straightforward for schools to implement; and the reporting standards are both simple for students to understand, and complete in that they account for 100% of enrolled students."
Population Coverage: The population is the schools that comply to the CIRR standards.
Data Quality Assessments:
CIRR compliant schools follow standards including: 

1. CIRR schools survey students regarding their post-graduation career goals, which is submitted to auditors.

2. Outcomes data is audited yearly by a third party. 

The data is not representative of all bootcamps, only the bootcamps compliant with CIRR standards.

STW Relevant: The technology bootcamps information provided for each review will provide insight into educational pathways for STW. Additionally, Course Report publishes survey research reports, so Course Report may have administrative data they use to supplement their survey reports.
Subject: Education Training Licenses/Certifications
Purpose: Course report reviews and researchs technology education. Each review first lists city, cost, skills learned, and courses available.
Data Quality Assessments: The Course Report data could be compared to other review sites such as SwitchUp. The Course Report data may not contain the entire universe of technology boot camps.
Notes: Course Report Research: https://www.coursereport.com/resources/research-reports

STW Relevant: Many of the queries relate to skills, for example, "advanced excel" is a query. STW skills can be searched if listed in the query terms to see what MOOC opportunities are available to learn these skills.
Subject: Education
Purpose: Coursera provides massive open online courses (MOOCs), specializations, certificates, and degrees. The directory can be searched by course, specialization, certificate, degree, topics, and queries.
Data Quality Assessments: The data only includes Coursera MOOCs, which are not representative of all MOOCs.

STW Relevant: Some observations of credentials include relevant O*net codes and SOC codes, which could be connected to relevant STW occupations.
Subject: Education, Apprenticeships, Licenses/Certifications
Purpose: "Credential Registry uses open-licensed software to continuously capture, connect, archive and share metadata about credentials, credentialing organizations, quality assurance organizations and competency frameworks and additional metadata as needed to support an open applications marketplace."
Population Coverage: The population is credentials in the credential finder system.
Data Quality Assessments: Credential Engine has an advisory group on quality assurance and its own benchmarking system, but surveys to benchmark the data with are not clear.
Notes:
Advisory Group: https://credentialengine.org/advisory-groups/quality-assurance/

Benchmarking system: https://credentialengine.org/2019/01/31/benchmark-data-model-a-best-practice-for-publishing/

Data Source Name: Data at Work, University of Chicago
STW Relevant: This relates to the STW because it normalizes job and skill titles, which may ease the search for STW jobs and skills. Additionally, the source allows searching for job titles by O*NET codes, so O*NET codes related to the STW could be searched to provide a list of STW job titles. The source also allows searching for skills related to jobs, jobs related to skills, as well as jobs related to other jobs and skills related to other skills. The Open Skills Project provides information on the relationship between jobs and skills, which can be used to explore the relationship between STW jobs and STW skills.
Subject: Jobs, Licenses/Certification, Training
Purpose: "The Open Skills Project is a public-private partnership lead by the University of Chicago focused on providing a dynamic, up-to-date, locally-relevant, and normalized taxonomy of skills and jobs that builds on and expands on the Department of Labor’s O*NET data resources. It’s aim is to improve our understanding of the labor market and reduce frictions in the workforce data ecosystem by enabling a more granular common language of skills among industry, academia, government, and nonprofit organizations."
Audience: Organizations who have interest in skill classification (i.e. businesses, academia, government, etc.)
Data Quality Assessments: The skills and jobs titles could be compared to other sources of job and skill name taxonomy, such as EMSI Skills.
Notes: API: http://api.dataatwork.org/v1/spec/. The job listings data sources are converted into a common job listing format, based on the schema.org Job Posting Schema (https://schema.org/JobPosting).

Data Source Name: Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics (NCES)                        https://nces.ed.gov/
STW Relevant: College Navigator is a free consumer information tool designed to help students, parents, high school counselors, get information about post-secondary information by location, institution type, and degree type. The Navigator provides information on more than 7,000 two- and four-year institutions, as well as career and technical schools.
Subject: Education
Purpose: The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES), a division of the U.S. Department of Education, is the primary federal entity responsible for collecting and analyzing data related to postsecondary education in the United States.  Each year, NCES collects a broad range of information from post-secondary institutions through the Integrated Post-secondary Education Data System.  Much of this information is then sorted, organized, and presented to the public on the College Navigator website, which is managed by NCES.

Data Source Name: Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics (NCES)                        https://nces.ed.gov/
STW Relevant: This source can be used for assessing relationship between job skills and education level. Specifically, the PIAAC tests adults on their literacy, numeracy, and problem-solving in technology rich environments. There is also a questionairre that asks about educational background, workplace experiences and skills, occupational attainment, and skills use (math, information/communication technology, reading, writing) in work and life.
Dataset Name: Program for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC)
Subject: Education
Purpose: The goal of PIAAC is to assess and compare the basic skills and the broad range of competencies of adults around the world. The assessment focuses on cognitive and workplace skills needed for successful participation in 21st-century society and the global economy. PIACC assesses in 4 domains: literacy, numeracy, problem solving in technology-rich environments, and reading components.
Population Coverage: Minimum of 5000 first round, 3660 adults in the second
Unit of Analysis: Adults in US households and prisons
Data Dictionary Link: There is a codebook on this page: http://www.oecd.org/skills/piaac/publicdataandanalysis/
Data Quality Assessments:
"PIAAC assessment questions are developed in a collaborative, international process. PIAAC assessment questions were based on frameworks developed by internationally known experts in each subject or domain. Assessment experts and developers from ministries/departments of education and labor and OECD staff participated in the conceptualization, creation, and extensive year-long reviews of assessment questions. In addition, the PIAAC Consortium's support staff, assisted by expert panels, researchers, and working groups, developed PIAAC's Background Questionnaire. The PIAAC Consortium also guided the development of common standards and procedures for collecting and reporting data, as well as the international "virtual machine" software that administers the assessment uniformly across countries. All PIAAC countries follow the common standards and procedures and use the virtual machine software when conducting the survey and assessment. As a result, PIAAC can provide a reliable and comparable measure of literacy skills in the adult population of participating countries.

Before the administration of the assessment, a field test was conducted in the participating countries. The PIAAC Consortium analyzed the field-test data and implemented changes to eliminate problematic test items or revise procedures prior to the administration of the assessment."
Notes: This survey is developed under the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Data Source Name: Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics (NCES)                        https://nces.ed.gov/
STW Relevant: Geographically overlay community, school, and employment indicators
Subject: Education
Purpose: The Department of Education’s (ED) National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) collects the school attendance boundaries biennially from geographically defined schools districts in the 50 States and the District of Columbia. A school attendance boundary (also referred to as a catchment area) is a geographic area from which the students are eligible to attend a local school. Typically, a local school district (also referred to as a local education agency (LEA)) determines the school attendance boundaries for schools within its district.
Data Quality Assessments: See Methodology Report Link

Data Source Name: Department of Education, Recognition and Accreditation                https://www.ed.gov/
STW Relevant: Contains information on community colleges and other non-degree credential institutions (for-profit and not-for-profit).
Dataset Name: Database of Accredited Postsecondary Institutions and Programs
Subject: Postsecondary Institutions and Programs
Purpose: The Database of Accredited Postsecondary Institutions and Programs contains information reported to the U.S. Department of Education directly by recognized accrediting agencies and state approval agencies. The database reflects additional information as it is received from recognized accrediting agencies and state approval agencies. This reported information is not audited. The U.S. Department of Education cannot, therefore, guarantee that the information contained in the database is accurate, current, or complete. For the most accurate and current information, contact the appropriate agency.
Data Quality Assessments: No
Notes:
This database is provided as a public service without warranty of any kind.
No technical assistance is available for the use of the file.
For current accreditation information about an individual institution/program, use the search options on the homepage.

Data Source Name: Department of Labor Employment & Training Administration Agricultural Workers
STW Relevant: Provides information about agricultural workers across US on individual level
Subject: Jobs/Employment
Purpose: Asks questions of agricultural workers about things such as Demographics, Household Composition, Adult Education, Languages, Work Experience, Residence, Current Job, Wages and Working Conditions, Work expectations, Income and Assets, and Legal Status
Data Quality Assessments:
"Interviews are allocated proportionately to each region/cycle strata based on the amount of farm labor in that region during that cycle. In every cycle, in each region, a random sample of FLAs is selected from a roster that is constructed from the universe of FLAs using probabilities proportional to the size of a given FLA's seasonal farm labor expenditures. Similarly, counties are randomly selected in each FLA using farm labor expenditures. Within each county, ZIP Code regions are randomly ordered.

The sampling frame of establishments (usually farms) engaged in Crop Production (NAICS 111) and Support Activities for Crop Production (NAICS 1151) is constructed primarily from the Quarterly Census of Employment and Wages (QCEW): a census of establishments that participate in the unemployment insurance (UI) program. In states where UI coverage is not universal, the sampling frame is supplemented with farm establishments drawn from commercial lists of agricultural employers, administrative data sources, internet searches, and discussions with local, knowledgeable sources."
Notes: Race is not listed but there is an "Indigenous/Non-indigenous"  measure based off an indigenous defintion that include "race, language and child language"

STW Relevant: Emsi provides data on location, job title, occupations, industry, companies, skills, which can be connected to the STW job titles, industries, and occupations. They also claim to have information about skill demand and supply, which could be connected to STW skill demand and supply.
Subject: Education Jobs/Employment Employers Industry
Purpose: The Emsi Workforce Development data aims to connect job candidates with employers by providing information on skills supplied by job candidates and skills demanded by employers. Emsi provides insight into online social profiles, job posting analytics, traditional labor market information, and compensation data.
Population Coverage: The data souce claims to cover 99.5% of employment.
Time Coverage: Emsi started partnering with workforce organizations in the early 2000s.
Data Dictionary Link: There is no data dictionary, but there is a search tool for Emsi terms: https://kb.economicmodeling.com/glossary/.
Data Quality Assessments:
EMSI data comes from the following sources listed below, so so EMSI data could be compared to data from the sources.

https://www.economicmodeling.com/data-sources/

STW Relevant: The EMSI Skills data could be an alternative to O*NET for classifying STW skills. The skills extractor could be used to find skills from job ads and resumes.
Subject: Education Training Licenses/Certifications
Purpose: "An open, comprehensive library of skills that uses the same terminology we use in the real world: nearly 30,000 skills (and counting) collected from hundreds of millions of job postings, resumes, and online profiles." The source also has an extraction tool that allows searching for skills in job ads and resumes.
Data Quality Assessments: The data can be compared to O*NET skills, but they do not follow the same taxonomy.
Notes: API Documentation can be found here: https://api.emsidata.com/apis/skills-classification#get-get-documentation

STW Relevant: This source relates to the STW, because the course data could be filtered by STW relevant subjects and skills. Additionally, edX provides certificate programs, which could be connected to the STW.
Subject: Education, Licenses/Certification
Purpose: edX is an open source, non-profit MOOC provider. The Course Search allows potential students to filter through edX's course offerings.
Data Quality Assessments: The edX data can be compared to MOOC review organizations, such as  Class Central.

STW Relevant: This data could be used to learn about students using edX MOOCS, specifically students in STW courses. There is course grades data, certificate data, and credit eligibility data, that would provide information about STW pathways, specifically, if those taking MOOCs are successfully passing, or receiving certificates and credit.
Dataset Name:
User Info and Learner Progress Data: 
Course Grades Data
Certificate Data
Credit Eligibility Data
Subject: Education, Licenses/Certification
Purpose: The edX Data Package allows partner institutions to research how learners interact wtih edX.
Data Quality Assessments: The edX data can be compared to MOOC review organizations, such as  Class Central.
Licensing or Training Required?: "To get access to the data package covering its courses, a partner institution must have an agreement with edX that includes data access."

STW Relevant: The NSLDS data can be used to see the loan amounts for students by institutions. If the data is connect with major data on the student-level, this would allow connecting loan amounts with STW majors.
Subject: Education, Student Loans
Purpose: "The National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS) is the U.S. Department of Education's central database for student aid. It receives data from schools, agencies that guaranty loans, the Direct Loan program, the Pell Grant program, and other U.S. Department of Education programs."
Audience: Guaranty Agencies, Lender/Lender Services, State Grant Agencies
Data Quality Assessments: NA
Notes: The NSLDS was not clear about what data will be included if access is granted, specifically for variables such as gender, race, location etc.

STW Relevant: TalentNeuron provides information about occupation, skills, and industry, that can be connected to the STW occupations, skills, and industries. TalentNeuron also has location data, so it may be possible to investigate STW occupation, skills, and industries by location provided.
Subject: Jobs/Employment
Purpose: We gather talent intelligence on key roles by location, occupation and skill set; data on where competitors are hiring and which skills and roles they are seeking; and location intelligence on where to find and hire top talent at the right price. The promotional videos indicate the 65,000 data sources are not self-reported data.
Population Coverage: Gartner collects supply and demand data from 65,000 global sources.
Data Quality Assessments: The data could be compared with other proprietary sources, such as the EMSI data or Location, Inc. data. Since the data is proprietary, there is no detailed information regarding what variables are a part of the dataset, so it is unclear what exactly can be compared. Additionally, Gartner says they collect data from 65,000 sources but do not specify what those sources are on their website.

STW Relevant: Job titles and industries in the Labor Market Report data can be connected to STW job titles and industries, indicating median salary and pay over time.
Subject: Jobs/Employment Industry
Purpose: The Glassdoor Job Market Report provides a real-time view of job and hiring trends and wage growth in the U.S., including several metro areas, based on millions of online jobs and salaries on Glassdoor. We publish the report monthly with the goal of offering labor market data, trends and analysis to help people make more informed job decisions and to help employers refine recruiting and hiring efforts.
Population Coverage: Job postings are collected from over 93,000 US employers.
Data Quality Assessments: The methodology document indicates the Glassdoor median pay data can be compared with the US Bureau of Labor Statistics Labor Force Statistics form the Current Population Survey. Additioanl benchmarks include the BLS Employment Cost Index and the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta's Wage Growth Tracker.
Notes:
FAQs: https://www.glassdoor.com/research/app/uploads/sites/2/2019/04/FAQ.Glassdoor-Job-Market-Report-1.pdf

Per the FAQs, academic researchers interested in using the Job Market Report data can email economics@glassdoor.com

STW Relevant: The Open Badges data provides standards for digital badges, so the source may have data regarding STW digital badge credentials. Additionally, IMS Global has a list of digital badge products that comply with Open Badges standards.
Subject: Education, Licenses/Certifications
Purpose: The Open Badges standard describes a method for packaging information about accomplishments, embedding it into portable image files as digital badges, and establishing resources for its validation and verification. In other words, Open Badges contain detailed metadata about achievements such as who earned it, who issued it, the criteria required, and in many cases even the evidence and demonstrations of the relevant skills.
Population Coverage: The population coverage is not listed.
Notes:
https://www.imsglobal.org/activity/digital-badges#digcredpublic

https://site.imsglobal.org/certifications?page=2&refinementList%5Bstandards_lvlx%5D%5B0%5D=Open%20Badges

STW Relevant: Jobs and education listed on the resumes could be connected to STW occupation, industry, or education titles, to gain a better understanding of the experience that STW workers have.
Subject: Education, Employment
Purpose: Indeed connects job-seekers to jobs by allowing them to post resumes and research employers. The Indeed Resume search tool allows employers to search for job candidates by job title, location, company, education, skills, and experience.
Data Quality Assessments: A bias of the data is that it only includes resumes upload to Indeed. It would be interesting to compare the data from Indeed to the Burning Glass Technologies data.

STW Relevant: This data contains information about skills, jobs, and education of STW, as well as companies that hire STW. It can also be used to create a job history for STW.
Subject: Education Licenses/Certifications Jobs/Employment Employers Industry
Purpose: The LinkedIn Developers data provides an API for developers to use basic member profile data. Fields include industry, location, position, company, education, certifications, and skills field.
Population Coverage: The population includes LinkedIn members and company members, but the coverage is not specified.
Data Quality Assessments:
The data could be compared to Indeed.com, Monster, and Burning Glass Technologies data.

It is important to note that some of the fields, such as the certification field, must receive approval from LinkedIn to use.

A bias is that it only contains LinkedIn members.

STW Relevant: The data is relevant to STW because it provides information on employers and workers. Additionally, LinkedIn's Economic Graph conducted research into the skills gap, so it is likely they have relevant data on skills mismatch. Since not much information about the data is listed on the website, they should be contacted to understand more about the data.
Subject: Education Licenses/Certifications Jobs/Employment Employers Industry
Purpose: The Economic Graph Research Program is an initiative in which LinkedIn works with academic researchers to conduct research that relates to creating economic opportunity for members of the global workforce and helping them be more productive and successful.
Population Coverage: The population includes LinkedIn members and company members.
Data Quality Assessments:
The data could be compared to the LinkedIn Developers API data, or Burning Glass Technologies, Monster, and Indeed.com data. 

It is important to note that there is an application process to be a part of the LinkedIn Economic Graph program, and on the website, the last round of applications was in 2018. It would be worth reaching out to them as this project is in line with their mission to create economic opportunity for every member of the global workforce".
Funding amount to support R&D: Not specified, but there is a process for applying to be a part of the Economic Graph program: https://engineering.linkedin.com/teams/data/projects/economic-graph-research/economic-graph-details#submission
Notes:
Article from the Economic Graph on the skills gap: https://economicgraph.linkedin.com/blog/Quantifying-skills-gaps-with-the-economic-graph

There is not much information provided on the website so LinkedIn Economic Graph should be contacted.

STW Relevant: The data contains information on the occupation and industry of residents in neighborhoods. The occupations and industries could be connected to STW industries and occupations to provide a better understanding of where the STW workforce lives, or where there may be a lack of workers in the geography.
Subject: Jobs/Employment Industry
Purpose:
"Location, Inc. uses hundreds of raw inputs to produce proprietary lifestyle, demographic, and neighborhood data for every neighborhood, school district, municipality, and state in the nation."

The data is from the proprietary NeighborhoodScout, which brings together government sources to create profiles on the neighborhood, city, and town levels.
Population Coverage: The data claims to cover all of the United States.
Data Quality Assessments: The Industry and Occupations data could be compared to the Current Population Survey, which provides data on occupations and industries.

STW Relevant: This source claims to have data on skills, credentials, job titles, and locations that can be connected to the STW industry and occupation codes. This can potentially help better understand career progressions, skill match, and education for STW.
Subject: Education Training Licenses/Certifications Jobs/Employment Employers Industry
Purpose:
"Monster’s Real-Time Labor Intelligence research provides the right data, analysis, and insights to help speed employment, address skill gaps, expand industries, and create new academic programs."

The Monster data uses 25 million Monster resumes, data mining for skills, credentials, job titles, and locations, Monster job ads, and job ads from job boards, government, non-profits, and industry association sites, modeled economic data, and education data.
Population Coverage: The population is 25 million Monster resumes.
Data Quality Assessments:
A bias of the data is that it only uses resumes from Monster. The information posted on the website is not clear about where the education, economic, and other sources of job ad data are from.

A potential quality assessment would be to compare the data to the Burning Glass Technologies data. 

These external sources may also be helpful in determining the quality of the data:

http://maryannfeldman.web.unc.edu/data-sources/jobs-workforce-education-labor-markets/monster-real-time-labor-intelligence/

https://www.c2er.org/download/2011-11/11-01-11_Presentation.pdf
Notes: More information here:https://www.monstergovernmentsolutions.com/docs/RealTimeLaborIntelligence5.pdf

STW Relevant:
The data includes the level and CIP code of the highest credential earned for a student at a university; these levels include associate and certificate. There is also information about industry credential organizations and credential/certification names. The CIP codes can be connected to STW CIP codes to gain a better understanding of enrollment in STW educational programs.

There is also a StudentTracker for High School students, which could provide additional information on the individual student, specifically, the high school attended and high school graduation date.
Subject: Education
Purpose: StudentTracter contains data about college enrollment and degrees, including two-year, trade school, and vocational school institutions.
Population Coverage: There are 3600 colleges covered in the data, or 99% of enrolled students.
Data Quality Assessments: The National Student Clearinghouse data could be compared to the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System data.
Notes:
Reporting of NSC Additional Data Elements:
https://nscresearchcenter.org/wp-content/uploads/Reporting_of_NSC_Additional_Data_Elements.pdf

StudentTracker® for Colleges & Universities User Manual:
https://studentclearinghouse.info/onestop/wp-content/uploads/STCU_User_Manual.pdf

STW Relevant: Some of the certification providers are related to the skilled technical workforce, such as Cisco, Juniper, and IBM. Although not listed on the website, it may be worth contacting National Student Clearinghouse Verification Services to see if they have administrative data on the certifications and licenses listed.
Subject: Licenses/Certifications
Purpose: The Professional Certification Verification Service from the National Student Clearinghouse verifies credentials for employers who are hiring.
Data Quality Assessments: The data could be compared against other sources of credential data that includes the same certification and licensure providers. The data is biased because it only includes 19 certification providers.
Notes: The fields left blank for this data source is because it is not listed on the website. National Student Clearinghouse Verification Services will need to be contacted to see if they have any sharable administrative data.

STW Relevant: The FedScope data has the variables: "Occupations" and "STEM Occupations" and "Education Level", which can be connected to the federal STW.
Subject: Jobs, Industry, Employers
Purpose: "The Office of Personnel Management is the focal point for providing statistical information about the Federal civilian workforce.  To satisfy customer's need for workforce data, FedScope was launched in the fall of 2000.  This online tool allows customers to access and analyze the most popular data elements from OPM's Enterprise Human Resources Integration-Statistical Data Mart (EHRI-SDM).  Customers include Federal government agencies, researchers, the media, and the general public."
Population Coverage: Federal workers, except from the following offices: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve, Central Intelligence Agency, Defense Intelligence Agency, Foreign Service personnel at the State Department (included until March 2006), National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, National Security Agency, Office of the Director of National Intelligence,  Office of the Vice President, Postal Regulatory Commission, Tennessee Valley Authority, U.S. Postal Service, White House Office, Foreign Nationals Overseas, Public Health Service’s Commissioned Officer Corps, Non-appropriated fund employees
Unit of Analysis: Employee (The data may be aggregated by race, gender, etc...)
Time Coverage: Quarterly data from 2009, Annual data from 1998
Data Dictionary Link: Data Dictionaries for each year and quarter are found here: https://www.opm.gov/data/index.aspx
Data Quality Assessments: NA

STW Relevant: This tool could be used to understand what soft and hard skills are relevant to STW careers, and how those careers are connected in a pathway. "PAIRIN Pathways provides personalized career path recommendations based on an individual’s readiness, desires and quality of the opportunity. The over 600 careers can be filtered by desired location, education requirements, job tasks, salaries, opportunity rating and so much more."
Subject: Job/Employment,
Purpose: PAIRIN Pathways matches job-seekers to career paths.
Geographic Unit: The location is available but the website is not specific about at what level.
Data Quality Assessments: NA
Notes:
This source is a proprietary search tool, butit may be useful to reach out to PAIRIN to inquire about how they connect skills to career pathways.

There is API information here: https://developers.pairin.com/pathways-api-staging

STW Relevant: This tool can be used to search a STW job and find skills relevant to that job.  The tool was developed using public O*Net APIs, so this could potentially be connected with O*Net codes.
Subject: Jobs/Employment
Purpose: This tool generates skills needed for job postings to aid skillls-based hiring.
Population Coverage: Jobs in the United States and the EU (the source used O*Net and ESCO APIs)
Data Quality Assessments: The Skillful Generator was created using information from EMSI, O*Net, and ECSO, so the data from the Generator could be connected or compared to these data sources.
Notes: A relevant article on the Skillful Generator: https://www.skillful.com/blog/announcing-new-employer-resource-skillful-job-posting-generator

STW Relevant: The programs partnered with Skills Fund offer STW training programs. It may be worth contacting Skills Fund because they may have more detailed and accessible data about loans and the programs they fund than what is listed on the website.
Subject: Education, Student Loans
Purpose:
Skills Fund provides loans for training programs, specifically coding, data science, UI/UX Design, Cybersecurity, Information Technology, Dental Assistant Training, Medical Assistant Training, Commercial Driver, Diesel Mechanic, and Lineman. Skills Fund has a screening process for schools that they finance, including acceptance rates, student outcomes, and curriculum. 

Skills Fund publishes Partner Spotlight where they provide information on program length, format (on-campus/online), cost, and career outcome.
Audience: Students looking for a loan for alternative training programs.
Population Coverage: The population of the data is the Skills Fund partner schools. There are approximately 70 partner schools, and about 50 partner schools/new partner articles.
Data Quality Assessments: Skills Fund is a stakeholder of the Council on Integrity in Results Reporting (CIRR), so it may be possible to compare Skills Fund data with CIRR data. A bias of the data is that the training programs reviewed must be a Skills Fund partner.
Notes: The location of programs can be found here: https://skills.fund/students.

STW Relevant: Gives information on how many have high school diplomas, and how this might break down over different demographics. Because data is provided at state level can be used for benchmark/description, but cannot be used for actual analysis.
Dataset Name: Education Attainment of the Adult Population by Race/Ethnicity
Subject: Education
Purpose: Educational attainment (high school diploma/bachelor's degree) by race/ethnicity/gender.
Data Quality Assessments: Because data is at state level, can easily be compared against other datasets.

STW Relevant: Along with rankings and reviews, each bootcamp listed has information such as course list, locations, online availability, cost, and program duration. It is not clear if this is part of the review response, or if this data is administrative and reported to SwitchUp by the bootcamp, so SwitchUp may need to be contacted. The data is relevant to STW because it provides information on training programs for coding bootcamps.
Subject: Education, Training
Purpose: "... SwitchUp is a free and comprehensive resource where prospective students can compare top-rated tech bootcamps and programs, read reviews, and get advice on switching to a career in web development, data science, UX/UI design, and more."
Population Coverage: The population is bootcamps, but the website is not clear on which bootcamps are included or not included in the data.
Data Quality Assessments: Reviews follow a verification process: https://www.switchup.org/ethics.

STW Relevant: The Conference Board Help Wanted OnLine® (HWOL) Index measures changes over time in advertised online job vacancies, reflecting monthly trends in employment opportunities across the US. The HWOL Data Series aggregates the total number of ads available by month from the HWOL universe of online job ads. Ads in the HWOL universe are collected in real-time from over 28,000 different online job boards including traditional job boards, corporate boards, social media sites, and smaller job sites that serve niche markets and smaller geographic areas.
Subject: Online job-ads
Purpose: The Conference Board is the member-driven think tank that delivers trusted insights for what’s ahead. Founded in 1916, we are a non-partisan, not-for-profit entity holding 501 (c) (3) tax-exempt status in the United States. www.conference-board.org.
Data Quality Assessments: https://www.conference-board.org/pdf_free/press/2018%20HWOL%20Technical%20Note7.pdf
Notes: The Conference Board and Burning Glass Technologies Announce Help Wanted OnLineTM Collaboration https://www.burning-glass.com/blog/conference-board-burning-glass-announce-help-wanted-online-collaboration/ (last accessed September 11, 2019)

STW Relevant: The website is vague, but TORQworks could be contacted to see inquire about any data they have on work and education experience, and employers, which could be connected to STW education and work.
Subject: Education, Jobs/Employment
Purpose: TORQ is a web application that empowers job seekers to take on new jobs and career paths using our powerful, unique TORQ algorithm - and gives employers and workforce professionals rock-solid skills validation for their hiring needs. The core TORQ algorithm gives candidates unbiased insights into the paths that their experience, education, and talents can unlock; and gives employers a larger, broader talent pool to help them find just the right fit.
Data Quality Assessments: The website is vague, so TORQworks would have to be contacted to assess data quality.

STW Relevant:
The five programs offered by Trilogy Education Services offer skills training in the STW domain. The data will provide information on which universities offer the programs and which companies hire the program completers. 

There is no official dataset from Trilogy so the company will have to be contacted to request administrative data.
Subject: Education Training Employers
Purpose:
"Trilogy Education partners with universities to offer programs in Web Development, Data Analytics, UX/UI Design, FinTech, and Cybersecurity."

Each program has an "Explore the Curriculum" link, which lists specific skills learned in each program. Trilogy Ed also partners with universities and employers.
Audience: Universities interested in partnering with Trilogy to offer bootcamps.
Population Coverage: Trilogy partners with 49 universities sand over 3000 companies, so there should be adminstrative data on these partnerships.
Data Quality Assessments: A bias of the data is that the data only includes Trilogy Education Services program partnerships.
Notes: There is no official dataset from Trilogy Education Services. The company will have to be contacted.

Data Source Name: U.S. Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics (NCES)                        https://nces.ed.gov/
STW Relevant: Can filter for school type 3 (vocational) to assess how many/where vocational schools are and to assess enrollment information.
Subject: Education
Purpose: The Elementary/Secondary Information System (ElSi) is an NCES web application that allows users to quickly view public and private school data and create custom tables and charts using data from the Common Core of Data (CCD) and Private School Survey (PSS).
Data Quality Assessments: Collects data from National Public Education Financial Survey (State Fiscal), State Dropout and Completion Data File, State Nonfiscal Public Elementary/Secondary Education Survey, State-Level Public School Dropout Data, Local Education Agency (School District) Universe Survey, Local Education Agency (School District) Universe Survey Dropout and Completion Data, Local Education Agency (School District) Universe Survey Geographic Data (EDGE), School District Finance Survey (F-33), Public Elementary/Secondary School Universe Survey, Public Elementary/Secondary School Universe Survey Geographic Data (EDGE), Private School Universe Survey (PSS), Public Elementary/Secondary School Universe Survey Geographic Data (EDGE)

Data Source Name: U.S. Department of Education, Office of Career, Technical, and Adult Education (OCTAE)                 https://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ovae/index.html
STW Relevant: Gives information on what fields CTE students are in. Only has data at state level, so can be used as descriptor or for baseline, but not for analysis. May able to request more information at perkins-help@rti.org.
Subject: Education
Purpose: Information on the secondary and postsecondary enrollment distribution of CTE concentrators in different fields. Definition of concentrator varies by state, but the Department of Education generally defines a secondary concentrator as "A secondary student who has earned three or more credits in a single CTE program area (e.g., health care or business services), or two credits in a single CTE program area, but only in those program areas where two-credit sequences at the secondary level are recognized by the state and/or its local eligible recipients" and a postsecondary concentrator as "A postsecondary or adult student who (1) completes at least 12 academic or CTE credits within a single program area sequence that is composed of 12 or more academic and technical credits and terminates in the award of an industry-recognized credential, a certificate, or a degree; or (2) completes a short-term CTE program sequence of less than 12 credit units that terminates in an industry-recognized credential, a certificate, or a degree"
Data Quality Assessments: Because data is at state level, can easily be compared against other datasets. perkins-help@rti.org may have more information.

Data Source Name: U.S. Department of Education, Office of Career, Technical, and Adult Education (OCTAE)                 https://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ovae/index.html
STW Relevant: Gives information on what fields CTE students are in. Only has data at state level, so can be used as descriptor or for baseline, but not for analysis. May able to request more information at perkins-help@rti.org.
Subject: Education
Purpose: Information on enrollment distribution of CTE participants in different types of schools: secondary, postsecondary, adult, secondary tech prep, postsecondary tech prep. Although the definitions of CTE participants vary among states, generally states define CTE participants as students who have completed one or more CTE courses at the secondary level or one or more credits at the postsecondary level.
Data Quality Assessments: Because data is at state level, can easily be compared against other datasets. perkins-help@rti.org may have more information.

Data Source Name: U.S. Dept. of Labor, Employment and Training Administration (USDOL/ETA), O*NET
STW Relevant: STW careers and industries can be searched in the My Next Move search tools to gather information on the knowledge, skills, abilities, personality, technology, education, job salary,  job posting, and related careers.
Subject: Education, Industry, Employers, Licenses/Certifications, Apprenticeships, Training, Jobs/Employment, Employers, Industry
Purpose: "My Next Move is an interactive tool for job seekers and students to learn more about their career options. My Next Move has tasks, skills, salary information, and more for over 900 different careers. Users can find careers through keyword search; by browsing industries that employ different types of workers; or through the O*NET Interest Profiler, a tool that offers personalized career suggestions based on a person's interests and level of work experience."
Population Coverage: United States job titles and industries.
When does the data become available?: Not specified forMy Next Move, but O*NET publishes data yearly.
Can the data be trended?: The My Next Move data is not listed over time, but the O*Net data can be trended.
Data Dictionary Link: The My Next Move data does not have a data dictionary, but the associated O*NET website has a data dictionary: https://www.onetcenter.org/dictionary/24.0/text/
Data Quality Assessments: The salary information could be compared to the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Occupational Employment Statistics .
Licensing or Training Required?: Must link to the license: https://www.mynextmove.org/help/license/
Notes:
There are multiple O*NET technical reports here:https://www.onetcenter.org/database.html.    Reserch report: Using the Department of Labor’s “My Next Move” to Improve Career Preparedness
Daniel J. KoysFirst Published September 12, 2016 Research Article https://doi.org/10.1177/1052562916670195

STW Relevant: Udacity has programs and courses that teach skills relevant to STW. The Program Catalog allows navigation to a page for each program, which contains a syllabus, estimated time commitment, and prerequisites. Additionally, the Program catalog can be filtered by industry skills, which can be connected to STW skills.
Subject: Education
Purpose: Udacity provides massive open online courses (MOOCs). The Program Catalog lists each available program from Udacity.
Data Quality Assessments: The data only includes Udacity MOOCs, which are not representative of all MOOCs.

Data Source Name: US Dept. of Labor, Employment and Training Administration (USDOL/ETA), Career One Stop
STW Relevant: The My Skills My Future data connects a job seeker's prior or current job with other related jobs. For the related jobs, there is information about typical pay, training, employers, and typical skills and training. The job-seeker can also compare their current job with other potentials jobs by salaries, skills, potential knowledge gaps, level of training, and licenses/certifications. STW jobs could be searched using this tool to explore pathways for the STW.
Subject: Jobs/Employment, Industry, Employers, Licenses/Certifications
Purpose: My Skills My Future allows a job seeker to search their current or past job, and find information about similar careers.
Data Quality Assessments: The salary information could be compared to the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Occupational Employment Statistics .
Notes: There is a link from My Skills My Future that links to the Career One Stop API, so it is possible that this information could be acquired through API rather than webscrape. The data sources used to construct My Skills My Future are listed at: https://www.myskillsmyfuture.org/skillstransferability/CareerMatchesPageHelp.aspx

STW Relevant:
WorkCred is invested in developing the credentialing system, and as such, participates in research about the credentialing system. It is likely that they have data about credentials for the STW. WorkCred has conducted previous research with survey data, but it is possible that they have administrative data.

There is no official data set on the WorkCred website, but their research interests are found here. They note that organizations that want to collaborate with WorkCred should email WorkCred.
Subject: Education, Licenses/Certifications
Purpose:
"Workcred’s research services include partnerships and grants to examine workforce credentialing issues and needs, and are currently focused on several key areas."

Their relevant research interests are Mapping the Credentialing Landscape, Globalization of Credentials, Alignment of Credentials in an Industry, and Stacking of Credentials.
Audience: Organizations interested in improved credentialing systems.
Data Quality Assessments: Since there is not official dataset and WorkCred will have to be contacted to see if they have sharable data, we cannot assess the quality of the data.
Notes:
There is no official data set on the WorkCred website, but their research interests are found here: https://workcred.org/Programs-and-Services/Research.aspx. They note that organizations that want to collaborate with WorkCred should email WorkCred.

Example publication: https://workcred.org/Documents/NIST-MEP-Report.pdf
